articles.headline: Hungary, Once a Star, Loses Its Shine
articles.snippet: The country serves as a cautionary tale for those who argue that Greece could regain competitiveness by reintroducing its currency.
articles.abstract: The country serves as a cautionary tale for those who argue that Greece could regain competitiveness by reintroducing its currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Zoltan Zsoter, an 80-year-old retiree, would seem to be about as far from the world of currency speculation as a person can get. Yet he is an example of how the workings of the global financial system, amplified by the policies of a single political leader, can have a devastating effect on ordinary people.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Palko Karasz

articles.headline: Iran Face-Off Testing Obama the Candidate
articles.snippet: The president, trying to contain Iran’s nuclear ambitions, must balance choices that could harm either the economic recovery or his image as a firm leader.
articles.abstract: The president, trying to contain Iran’s nuclear ambitions, must balance choices that could harm either the economic recovery or his image as a firm leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The escalating American confrontation with Iran poses a major new political threat to President Obama as he heads into his campaign for re-election, presenting him with choices that could harm either the economic recovery or his image as a firm leader.

articles.headline: Euro Woes Could Revive Bout of Market Volatility
articles.snippet: Renewed gloom about the debt crisis in Europe threatens to end the calm that has prevailed on Wall Street in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: Renewed gloom about the debt crisis in Europe threatens to end the calm that has prevailed on Wall Street in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors are bracing for a return to volatility when markets in the United States reopen on Tuesday as renewed gloom about the debt crisis in Europe threatens to end the calm that has prevailed on Wall Street in recent weeks.

articles.headline: Web Gang Operating in the Open
articles.snippet: The Koobface gang, a Russian-based group, has grown wealthy by apparently spreading a computer worm on Facebook and other social networks and cashing in on various schemes.
articles.abstract: The Koobface gang, a Russian-based group, has grown wealthy by apparently spreading a computer worm on Facebook and other social networks and cashing in on various schemes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five men believed to be responsible for spreading a notorious computer worm on Facebook and other social networks — and pocketing several million dollars from online schemes — are hiding in plain sight in St. Petersburg, Russia, according to investigators at Facebook and several independent computer security researchers.

articles.headline: Learning to Be Lean
articles.snippet: Health insurers and employers must now pay to screen children for obesity and provide them with counseling. Experts say creating such programs will be a challenge.
articles.abstract: Health insurers and employers must now pay to screen children for obesity and provide them with counseling. Experts say creating such programs will be a challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: As one of the many outgrowths of the sweeping federal health care law, health insurers and employers must now pay the cost of screening children for obesity and providing them with appropriate counseling.

articles.headline: The Invisible Hand Behind Bonuses on Wall Street
articles.snippet: Compensation consultants work in the shadows to help Wall Street banks and other financial institutions set bonuses and devise severance packages.
articles.abstract: Compensation consultants work in the shadows to help Wall Street banks and other financial institutions set bonuses and devise severance packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: When asked about his job at cocktail parties, Alan Johnson has a curiosity-piquing line.

articles.headline: Young U.S. Citizens in Mexico Brave Risks for American Schools
articles.snippet: Called “transfronterizos,” these students migrate between two nations every day, straining the resources of public school districts and sparking debate among educators.
articles.abstract: Called “transfronterizos,” these students migrate between two nations every day, straining the resources of public school districts and sparking debate among educators.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — Weekday mornings at 5, when the lights on distant hillsides across the border still twinkle in the blackness, Martha, a high school senior, begins her arduous three-hour commute to school. She groggily unlocks the security gate guarded by the family Doberman and waits in the glare of the Pemex filling station for the bus to the border. Her fellow passengers, grown men with their arms folded, jostle her in their sleep.

articles.headline: Romney Is Opponents’ Main Target in G.O.P. Debate
articles.snippet: With five days remaining before the South Carolina primary, the Republican challengers wasted little time firing pointed questions at Mitt Romney during Monday night’s debate in Myrtle Beach.
articles.abstract: With five days remaining before the South Carolina primary, the Republican challengers wasted little time firing pointed questions at Mitt Romney during Monday night’s debate in Myrtle Beach.
articles.lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Mitt Romney withstood forceful attacks during a debate here on Monday evening, with his Republican rivals lining up to question his job-creation record, wealth and character, as they implored voters to scrutinize his candidacy more deeply before allowing him to sail to the party’s presidential nomination.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg
